document.text: Sheriffs Sale of Land in Appomattox County, Va. I will, on Thursday, the 20th day of June, 1895, sell at public auction, on the premises, in pursuance of an order of the county court of Appo- mottox county entered at he Feb ruary term, 1895, the tract of land belonging to John Mehan, situated near Hixburg, in said county, adjoin ing the lands of L. R. Glenn and others, and which was purchased by said Mehan from Wm D. Hix. This sale is to satisfy an execution in my hands in favor of the said Wm. D. Hix, the amount of said execution being 40.84, with interest on 32.- 40, from 1 st day of January, 1893, and the cost of executing this sale. The sale will take place at 11 oclock, A. M. Terms of sale Ca 3 h. S. P. Coleman, Sheriff of Appomattox Co. 20-4t

document.text: S o u th s id e . How is this for winter? We just fee like saying, I told you s, to the many who have predicted th t we- were not going to have any had Wnther flnd that the beautiful snow would be conspicuous by its absence. We think that every one will be able to fill their ice houses if the weather continues cold a few days. Farmers have been plowing and burning plant hinds, but this cold spell will give them more time to talk of the new railway route proposed by .he N.  W. Your correspondent heard to-day that it is thought it will come by Caldwells mill and strike Evergreen about at Mr. Hudson Ch at hams. To such lengths will peoples imagination carry them, and we expect the hair on many a young head will be white before that comes to pass. We are sorry to le irn of the con tinued illness of Mrs. Alice Wool dridge, at the home of M r. Robt Wooldridge, of your town, We trust that she may soon be well enough to be taken home. The family of Mr. T. A. Coleman moned in their sabstantix new home a6t week. Mr. Coleman is somewhat improved. Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Odor movsd to h is - brothers farm near Reedy Springs last week. We are sorry to lose them from this neighborhood. Ex Sheriff S. P. Coleman and son, J. T. were in Lunenburg on a bu siness trip recently. Rev. George Chockley preached a fine sermon at Reedy Springs 4th Sunday morning. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Holycro. have moved to the old Cbleman homestead. We welcome them to our community. Mrs. S. P. Coleman is still quite unwell. We were sorry to hear of the ill ness of Mr. Ed. Woolridge. Mrs. Lee McCormick, of Lynch burg, who has been on a visit to her parents Mr. ano Mrs. Will,tam Macii, has returned home.  Mr. Early Mann, who s workin near Petersb rg, spent Sunday with bis home people. Several members of Mr. Neal Harveys family have been sick. Mr. Geo. Coleman of Souih N oifo k, and Mr. Maynard Fowlkes attended services at Salem and vis ited relatives near Reedy Springs 3rd Sunday.

document.text: Mr. A. H. Clement desires it to be understood that he is in the can vass and will endeavor to visit the homes of the people of the county, but that he has been interfered with n some respects by unforeseen cir cumstances. The Baptist ministers of the Ap pomattox Association will meet to day to discuss the needs of the field ind to arrange a tentative program for the Association which meets at Charlotte C. H., August 18. Rev. Hugh Smith attends from this place. Capt. R. S. Echols, who was so badly injured by the wreck between Petersburg and Richmond last Fri day and who was reported to have been killed, is now here on a fair way to permanent recovery. Engi neer Covington and Fireman Cov ington, of the ill-fated train, were killed. All of these gentlemen were well and favorably known in this, county. The following officers qualified on Monday before Judge Christian in the county court, their terms being extended to January 1,1904, under the new Constitutiou S. P. Coleman, sheriff Leon. E. Smith, commissioner of revenue J. W. Paris, superintendent of poor J. R. Horsley, county surveyor W. H. Ligon, J. C. Jones, supervisors. R. F. Burke qualified as treasurer, vice l. Mott Robertson, resigned. It is rumored that T. J. Stratton will stand for road Commissioner in Stonewall, J. F. Dickerson for Gloyer Hill, and Hon. J. C. Jones- and Saml Lee has announced them selves candidates in Southside. No candidate has come out for Super visor for Stonewall, and Hon. W. Hi Ligon has no opposition in Clovef Hill for his old place on the board. Messrs. J. H. Robertson and Ed ward Harvey are candidates for Supervisor from Southside. Quite a surprise was sprung on the village yesterday when Mr. W. D. Cofer, came down from Blue field, W. Va., and secured a license for the marriage of Miss Lizzie Fleshman, which happy event will be celebrated to-day at the home of the brides father in a quiet way. The brides pastor Rev. Hugh C. Smith will officiate. The couple will leave on the evening train for a trip east and will be permanently located in Bluelield, where the groom holds a lucrative position with the N.  W. Ry. Co. The bride is a very charming young lady and de- servingly popular with

document.text: Let Us Have tbe School. E ditor T imbs  I saw an editorial in your excel lent paper some time ago, regarding a graded school at this place. I heartily concur with you about it. It is a good idea, and one that onr citizens shonld take hold of and stop talking of it as an impossibility. Certainly, there is nothing more needed in this vicinity than a good school. Look around here and see what poor advantages onr children have, oompared with the children of other counties. Prince Edward has, within its borders, both a male and female college. Buckingham,through the munificence of Gen. T. M. Lo gan, has a splendid graded school Charlotte and Campbell children both have advantages that are denied ours. If yon will stop a minute yon can see how easy we can get a school here, at a very little coat to any one person. If yon will allow me I will suggest a plan to get it np Suppose some of the leading young men take this m atter in hand and start a subscription to raise funds. We only need abont 500 to start on, and I am certain that the people of old Appomattox can raise it with very little trouble. I wonld Bnggest that Sheriff S. P. Coleman take one of the subscrip tion lists around, as he has proven himself very good at that kind of work and he wonld be particularly interested in this m atter as he has some little ones yet to be educated. Mr. R. F. Burke wonld also make an efficient solicitor, and he is deeply interested in the m atter. There are a number of others I could mention who will do all in their power for the school. I am a great believer in hitting while the iron is hot. - Now, as public opinion is some what aroused on this snbject, let the good people of Appomattox have a mass meeting to put the scheme on foot at once. As yon said in yonr editorial on this snbject, Rome was not bnilt in a day but I never saw a school house as large as the city of Rome, however. It will be remem bered that the founders of Rome went to work and worked hard until it was quite a city, well fortified. We do not wish to build a Rome, bnt a good school. Now let every man p at his shchlder to the wheel, and I am confident a suitable school house will be erected at this place in the nettfrfuture. J. A.

document.text: In Lim bo. The best piece of detective work hat has been done for some time, in his County, was done by Sheriff S. P. Coleman in the detection and rrest of Hugh Nixon, charged with Stealing an ox from Mr. Powhatan p.Goins, a citizen of this County. t seems that on or about the 20th of September last Mr. Goins lost an px which was his main stay in the preparation of his land for the crops, and Hugh Nixon having been seen Sn the neighborhood, the people began to suspect that he was guilty of the theft. A warrant was sworn out for his arrest and search was made for him but he was no where to be rfoiind. Our sheriff, who is always on the alert in apprehending and bringing before the Court all viola ters of the law, after weeks of labor in that direction, finally traced him to Richmond, and after he had fully satisfied himself as to his where jibouts, telegraphed the chief of Po lice of that City to arrest him, which was done immediately upon receipt of the telegram. Mr.  Coleman jin the discharge of his official duty, took Wade Scates to the Penitentary on Saturday and returning brought Nixon back with him. He is now safely lodged in jail to await his trial at the next term of the County Conrt. Nixon is a desperate character, bay mg been sentenced twice to impris ment in the State Penitentiary once or six years for horse stealing and or sixteen years for attempt at rape overnor McKinney however par ened him before he had served his entire term. If he is convicted this tone he will be sentenced for life, ping au old offender. Too much praise cannot he be stowed upon our Sheriff for the way in which he worked up the case against Nixou.

document.text: GINGERY. About the time Mr. Ligon had finished his speech, Sheriff Coleman approached him and spoke of a promise he Ligon had made him to vote against Major Lynn as Superin tendent of the Penitentiary, or help defeat the bill which allows the penitentiary guards to conduct pris oners to the penitentiary, instead of the sheriff8 as formerly. Mr. Ligon flatly denied that he ever made any such promise. The News has the following to say of the occurrence, which report bears the ear-marks of an eye-witness The closing scenes of the political meetiug at West Appomattox on Thursday were of a somewhat sensa tional nature. After Mr. H. D. Flood had concluded his eloquent address, Mr. W. H. Ligon, of Hix- burg, candidate for the House of Delegates, arose and made a few re marks, in the course of which he stated that the only promise he had made was that he would vote for John W. Daniel to succeed himself in the United States Senate. Mr. Ligon had finished bis speech and the crowd was pouring from the courthouse building when Mr. S. P. Coleman, sheriff of Appomattox county, Btepped up to Mr. Ligon and in a voice that was audible through out the building, declared that he had promised to vote against Major B, W. Lynn, in the election for superintendent of the State peniten tiary. As the crowd paused to listen to the controversy, Mr. Ligon turned to Mr. Coleman and denied having made any each promise, and declared that he had no intention of doing so. Then I will beat you, said Mr. Coleman, in a voice that showed ex citement. 1 will rnu for the leg islature as an independent candi date. Aa the audience turned again to leave the court-rocm, Mr. Ligon turned to them and said that be wanted it understood, chat be was going to represent the people of Ap pomattox, and that he intended to be gnided by their wishes.

document.text: County Court--July Term. Court was in session three days. Eleven deeds were admitted to record since June term. Joseph Button qualified as admr of his sister, Mrs. Carrie Coni bourn, lately deceased,  The will of Solomon Davis was admitted to probate. The will of Wm. A. White was admitted to probate, and Alfred A. White qualified as executor bond, 25,000. W. C. Abbitt and J. C. Shearer, justices-elect. for Stonewall district, who failed to qualify at June term, were appointed justices by the court and qualified ou Thursday. P. H. Fore, justice-elect for Clo ver-Hill district, failed to qualify in June, but was appointed and quali fied ou Thursday last. A. H. Howerton, D. A. Christian, Jr., and H. C. Babcock qualified as deputies of Treasurer Robertson. H. S. Coleman qualified as deputy to Sheriff S. P. Coleman. Retail liquor license was granted to W. T. White, West Appomattox. Dnun vs. Eubank, unlawful de tainer continued to next term. E. G. Harvey, a justice-elect for southsiae district, having failed to qualify, C. H. Godsey was appointed in his place, and qualified. J. R. Atwood vs. John M. Rey nolds, on attachment for debt judg ment for plaintiff sheriff ordered to advertise and sell defendants lot of land near this place. Commonwealth vs, Norfolk and Western Railway, on appeal from a justices court five cases, for run ning freight trains onSunday jury in each case tried gave a verdict for the Commouwealfh 50 to 75 fine and costs in each case. It is agreed that the railway company shall ap peal one case as a test. If the ap pellate court sustains this court, all the cases are to be pressed to execu tion  if the appellate court reverses this court,jll the five cases are to be dismissed.

document.text: TH E COUNTY CLERKSHIP. A right pretty political fight is to take place in this county for the clerkship, which is the best-paid office within the gift of our jieople The present clerk holds od for two more years, and then the will be made for an eight-year term Dr. D. Mott Robertson, late county- treasurer, who resigned that office last summer, has announced to sono of his friends that he will stand fo the Democratic nomination for tb clerkship, and that he will, if elect ed, run the office for the fees alone This would be a saving to the tax payers of nearly 600 per annum, or nearly 5,000 for thè term. The election is some distance be fore us, and it is not our purpose to stir up the candidates or the people upon the subject thus early  but we shall fill the field of a newspaper and keep our readers informsd of events as they occur. Among tbi possible candidates we feel warrant ed in mentioning our present sheriff. Mr. S. P. Coleman, who would be u formidable opponent for any aspir ant H. Winston McKinney, the ef ficient deputy clerk, who is perhapi more familiar with the duties of the office, and better qualified for theii discharge, than any other available man. Should he enter the race, he would undoubtedly have the warm support of Mr. George T. Peers, the present clerk  and Mr. Peers would, no doubt, remain in the office for a time to aid him in his work. Mr. J Rolfe Horsley, whom Mr. Peers de feated for the office in 1899, is also likely to be a candidate. Mr. Hors ley last Week resigned the position of private secretary to Congressman Flood, which oarried a salary of 1, 200 per annum paid by Congress and assumed the management of the Southside Virginian. The resigna tion of Mr. Horsley probably caused Dr. Robertsons early announcement of his candidacy. We are satisfied that there will be other candidates. The people are being quietly sounded as to thiB and that man, bat the great majority of them will hardly bind themselves to any one at this stage of the game- none, perhaps, except a few whc be lieve that they ought to be allowed  to shape all the public policies of the connty, and to name all of the officeholders years in advance of the election. We respectfully dissent, and Bhall await developments before we bind ourselves to the tail of any

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: vandalism, which occured Aug. 3-5 in the Spring Mill, Spout Spring, Stonewall and Oakville communities. Deputy Sheriff R. W. Baldwin and State Trooper Paul Kvasnicka made the arirests, according to the Sheriffs Office. Ayers and Kress are scheduled to appear in General District Court Aug. 27, and the juveniles will appear in Juvenile-Domestic Court Aug. 28, according to the Sheriffs Department. Police also arrested Groyer Lee Smith, age 19, of Concord and a juvenile last Thursday in connection with a separate vandalism incident in which a number of tombstones were overturned in the Concord Cemetary. Smith was scheduled to appear in court Wednesday, and the juveniles court date was set for Aug. 28. The investigation and arrests were made by C. H. Martin of the county Sheriffs Department. County police also made two arrests in connection with three break-ins, two of which occurred July 29, and one of -which happened Dec. 13 of last year. Valerie Louise Dixon and Brenda Leigh Coleman, both of Farmville, were arrested in connection with break-ins at the homes of Robert Gray two counts and James Frank Ranson, Jr. A break-in occurred at the Gray home on Dec. 13, 1979 and again on July 29 of this year. The Ranson home was broken into July 29 also. Sheriff J. E. Richardson, Deputy Sheriff B. P. S m and Deputy Sheriff C. A. Reynold! vest gated the cast add made the arrests. No court date had been set for the suspects as of press time.

document.text: This highly esteemed citizen of Appomattox passed away at Staunton Hospital Saturday. Deceased served this county as sheriff for 16 years and was a popular and prominent citizen. He was born July 26, 1847 ini this county and never lived at any other place. His remains were interred at the family grave yard at his late home Sunday afternoon in the presence of a large crowd of friends and relatives. Deceased is survived by the following children Mrs. J. S. Plunkett, Mrs. T. W. Odor, H. S. and J. T. Coleman, Mrs. C. T. Cawthorn, W. p. and Miss Emma Sue Coleman, all of Ap pomattox County. Rev. W. M. Thompson con ducted the service and Senator Ferguson spoke of the service and record of deceased at the  grave. He was a confederate  soldier. .
